IAM 101: RBAC, ABAC, and PBAC â€“ Choosing the Right Access Model

TL;DR

Access control models define who can access what within your systemsâ€”and more importantly, under what conditions. The most common modelsâ€”RBAC (Role-Based Access Control), ABAC (Attribute-Based Access Control), and PBAC (Policy-Based Access Control)â€”offer different strengths depending on your organizationâ€™s complexity, compliance needs, and operational maturity. In this post, weâ€™ll explore each model, compare real-world use cases, and help you decide which approach fits your identity strategy.

ğŸ” Background

In the IAM world, authorization is the engine that drives secure accessâ€”yet it’s also where things get messy. I’ve seen it firsthand during audits, mergers, app onboarding, and cloud migrations.

The first time I inherited a role matrix built on RBAC with 300+ overlapping roles? It was chaos. That was 2012. Since then, Iâ€™ve implemented cleaner, more scalable access control systems using ABAC and, in advanced cases, PBAC.

Choosing the right model isn’t just a technical decisionâ€”itâ€™s a governance one. It determines how granular, flexible, and enforceable your access policies will be across on-prem, cloud, SaaS, and hybrid environments.

ğŸ§± Access Control Models Explained

ğŸ” What is RBAC?

Role-Based Access Control assigns access based on job roles. Each role maps to a set of permissions, and users are assigned roles.

Example:

  • A user in the “HR Manager” role automatically gets access to Workday, Payroll, and Benefits Admin.

âœ… Pros:

  • Easy to understand and manage
  • Works well in stable orgs with clear job structures
  • Widely supported in enterprise systems

âŒ Cons:

  • Explodes in complexity as exceptions grow
  • Doesn’t scale well across dynamic environments
  • Often leads to â€œrole creepâ€ (users get too many roles)

ğŸ§  What is ABAC?

Attribute-Based Access Control goes beyond roles by evaluating attributesâ€”user department, location, device trust level, time of day, etc.

Example:

  • â€œAllow access to the finance dashboard if user.department = ‘Finance’ AND device.compliant = true AND location = ‘US’.â€

âœ… Pros:

  • Highly granular and dynamic
  • Ideal for modern, hybrid environments
  • Supports context-aware security

âŒ Cons:

  • Can be hard to audit or visualize
  • Policy logic can become complex
  • Needs clean, consistent attribute data

ğŸ“œ What is PBAC?

Policy-Based Access Control (often seen as an evolution of ABAC) centers around central, codified policies written in natural or declarative language.

Example:

  • â€œManagers can approve expense reports for direct reports under $5,000.â€
  • â€œDeny access to sensitive data unless classification = ‘Internal’ and user has completed training.â€

âœ… Pros:

  • Expressive, business-aligned policies
  • Useful in governance-heavy industries (finance, healthcare)
  • Enables Just-in-Time and risk-based access models

âŒ Cons:

  • Requires robust policy engine (like Axiomatics, PlainID)
  • Strong coordination between IAM and business units
  • Learning curve for authoring policies

ğŸ¢ Real-World Use Cases

ğŸ§¾ Healthcare Organization â€“ RBAC First, Then ABAC

A healthcare system I worked with started with classic RBAC (Doctors, Nurses, Admins) but added ABAC when telehealth rolled out. Now, patient records are only viewable if:

  • The user is assigned to the patientâ€™s care team
  • Access is from a compliant device
  • The shift is currently active

ğŸ›ï¸ Government Agency â€“ PBAC for Zero Trust

A federal agency uses PBAC to implement Zero Trust. Access is defined by central policies like:

â€œOnly users who have completed clearance check and are within U.S. jurisdiction may access classified documents.â€

Policies are enforced through integration with SIEM and UEBA tools that feed into dynamic risk scoring.

ğŸ“Š Cited Study

According to Gartnerâ€™s â€œMarket Guide for Attribute-Based Access Controlâ€ (2022), by 2026, 60% of enterprises will phase out pure role-based models in favor of attribute and policy-based methods to handle complex, dynamic workforces and multi-cloud access needs.

ğŸ”§ Implementation Tips for IT Teams

If you’re evaluating your access control strategy, here’s how I recommend approaching it:

1. Start Simple

Use RBAC to handle common, static job functions. Get your roles cleaned up and mapped properly.

2. Layer in ABAC Where Needed

Donâ€™t rip and replace. Add ABAC where roles fall shortâ€”like context-aware access, contractor logic, or hybrid user states.

3. Build Toward Policy Governance

If you’re in a regulated industry or preparing for Zero Trust, start introducing PBAC policies aligned to business outcomes (e.g., data classification, training completion, risk score).

4. Leverage Your IdP or IGA Platform

Modern IAM platforms like Okta, Azure AD, SailPoint, or Saviynt often support hybrid RBAC/ABAC logic. Use these tools to enforce least privilege dynamically.

5. Donâ€™t Skip Auditing and Review

No matter the model, ensure access is reviewed quarterly and attested by business owners.

ğŸ§­ Final Thoughts

Thereâ€™s no one-size-fits-all access model. But here’s how I like to think of it:

  • RBAC is great for static environments with clear roles.
  • ABAC is essential for dynamic, hybrid, and cloud-based work.
  • PBAC is your go-to when business rules drive accessâ€”or when regulators require explainability.

The best programs use a hybrid approachâ€”starting with RBAC for structure, layering ABAC for flexibility, and adopting PBAC for risk-based governance.

As identity professionals, our goal isn’t just granting accessâ€”it’s granting the right access, at the right time, for the right reason.
